Award.AwardTitle: EAGER Germination: Crystallizing Transformative Ideas by Seeding a Diverse Knowledge Community
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal from the University of Illinois aims to develop a learning framework and associated platforms that will increase the probability of germinating transformative research ideas that will open new opportunities to address important societal challenges. Although the framework is designed for any research domain, for evaluation purposes this project focuses on the interdisciplinary challenge of resilience to global climate change. The target audiences are late stage graduate students, early stage faculty, and postdoctoral scholars who show potential for engaging in cross-institutional interdisciplinary research linking scholars from American Indian Tribal Colleges, Historically Black Colleges and Universities, Hispanic-Serving Colleges and Universities, and Land Grant Universities.

Resilience to climate change is a fundamentally important issue and this project has the opportunity to generate new approaches to this challenge. The inclusion of minority serving institutions in a meaningful way that gives them true voice breaks new ground in this area of inquiry as well. Procedures that facilitate including multiple voices when addressing fundamental scientific challenges will be a contribution to building a commonwealth among the many groups in the US who have stakes in important scientific issues. Expected project outcomes will be: (1) Cross-institutional, interdisciplinary proposals to funding agencies; (2) Sustainable cross-institutional and interdisciplinary networks to promote future research; (3) A procedure for facilitating the first two outcomes and evidence for its efficacy, scalability, and adaptability beyond the institutions involved in the study. A team composed of research and STEM directors and other personnel from the American Indian Higher Education Council (AIHEC), the Hispanic Association of Colleges and Universities (HACU), and the National Association for Equal Opportunity in Higher Education (NAFEO), and directors and research scientists from the National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA), as well as other scholars and process experts will contribute to the development and implementation of the framework.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research on creativity and interdisciplinarity identifies conditions that increase the probability of hatching transformative research ideas that open new opportunities to address important societal needs. These include: (1) interaction of multiple, radically different perspectives on a research problem; (2) engaging in a structured collaboration process that sparks widespread search for ideas, creative recombination of ideas, and novel frameworks; and (3) working through cycles of (i) intensive ideation (to identify features of the problem and to suggest solutions); (ii) gestation (workgroups separate to develop solutions and pull in new resources/people); and (iii) crystallization (parties reconvene to distill best ideas, recalibrate to the challenge, and plan for implementation).

This project developed and implemented a learning framework and associated platforms that foster these conditions in order to germinate research projects addressing the grand challenge of resilience to climate change. The framework involved six stages: (1) Recruitment of 17 researchers from diverse institutional, disciplinary, ethnic, and racial backgrounds all of whom share an interest in addressing climate change. (2) Preparation by sharing literature and activities that fostered the identification of common ground, and the initial development of research questions that may be germinated into novel research projects. (3) An Ideation Workshop whose design drew from research on creativity and team formation to help participants identify common ground and germinate project ideas. (4) A Gestation Period during which teams developed their initial projects into draft proposals for research with specific funding agencies in mind. (5) A Crystallization Workshop where the cohort engaged in a focused feedback and revision of their proposals to ensure the greatest development possible prior to submission to funding agencies. (6) Follow-through & Final Evaluation to support the project teams as they made final pushes to submit their proposals and to assess and evaluate the program’s success.

The project resulted in the formation of five diverse cross-disciplinary teams, each with a specific targeted funding opportunity and a proposal in development related to climate resilience.  The 17 participants represented 9 distinct disciplinary identities and 13 academic institutions. Participants also represented a diversity of minority- and majority-serving institutions, including Hispanic serving institutions, historically black colleges and universities, land grant universities, and tribal colleges and universities. Together, the cohort generated 125 potential research problems addressing climate change, some of which they focused into 9 potential research projects. They selected five of these projects for further development.

One primary project outcome was these teams’ products. Each team produced a series of proposal documents designed to target specific calls from national funding agencies. One team’s proposal was selected for funding through a process of competitive review by the Environmental Protection Agency. Project teams have also generated several journal submissions within their home disciplines.

The evaluation process for the learning framework drew on a mixture of survey and interview data from participants, as well as external assessments of project documents. Both survey and interview data indicated that participants found the process to have helped them effectively form research collaborations with other scientists, and that the longitudinal design motivated them to continue pursuing these collaborations despite a number of extrinsic adverse pressures in their home institutions. External expert assessments of team project summaries indicated that the research projects generated through the framework were at least as creative as currently funded NSF research on climate change. Another key outcome of this project was production of a taxonomy describing the barriers participants experienced in their efforts to engage in cross-disciplinary and cross-institutional collaborations.

Together, these findings contribute to research on teams and science policy by demonstrating the important value of longitudinal and engaged support for enabling the successful formation and execution of interdisciplinary science. The framework offers a novel, comprehensive approach, which goes beyond techniques that offer procedural support for only some phases of the process.  It also brings together scholars from at least four groups with substantively different backgrounds in terms of life experience and culture, enabling us to assess the hypothesis that this approach will stimulate creative/transformational thinking beyond that achieved by more homogeneous groups. The results suggest the need for significant changes in research idea generation and proposal development procedures for projects sponsored by NSF and other agencies.

Beyond its implications for science policy, participants focused their efforts on an important issue of societal interest. The inclusion of minority-serving institutions in a meaningful way that gives them true voice broke new ground in this area of inquiry as well.  Procedures that can facilitate the inclusion of multiple viewpoints in the attempt to address scientific grand challenges contribute to building a commonwealth among the many groups affected by these challenges.  Finally, the project provided professional development for traditionally underserved populations.
